p: Metabolic disorders were characterized by intestinal inflammation and mucosal-barrier dysfunction, which facilitate the translocation of luminal toxicity into the host [ 50]. An HFD clearly damages intestinal barrier function and downregulates the major goblet cell mucin producing gene Muc2, antimicrobial gene Reg3g [ 51], and tight junction proteins ZO-1 and occludin in mice [ 52]. In contrast, the expression levels of these factors in the intestines were elevated by puerarin administration when compared to that in the HFD group ( Fig 6C, 6D and 6F), indicating that puerarin protected the integrity of the intestines.
